poem:
Title: On a Democracy's Stage

Pawns in a game of power,
Labour and Tory dance.
Neither angel nor devil,
each seeks his chance.
In their drama, expatriates play,
as pieces moved hither and yon.
A rigmaroled election unmasked,
in the cool dawn.
When the curtain descends at last,
will a just rule persist?
Or be replaced by echoing laughter,
drowned in the morning mist?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Britain’s party leaders should heed overseas voters’ concerns | Letters Polly Toynbee rightly brands the Tory move to re-enfranchise British expatriates as “gerrymandering” (First photo ID, now votes for expats: the Tories are showing us exactly what election rigging looks like, 6 February). But the same applies to Labour’s efforts to prevent it. Both parties want to game our electoral system – one by enfranchising expats, the other by excluding them. What Toynbee ignores are". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
